Assessment and Implications of Rationalizing and 
Phasing Out Fossil-Fuel Subsidies

designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Subsidies  are  one  of  the  many  policy  instruments  used  by  governments  to  attain 
socioeconomic  development  objectives.  Fossil-fuel  subsidies,  in  particular,  serve  such 
objectives by providing incentives to energy producers through an increase in  price or by 
redistributing wealth to the poor by reducing the price of energy products. Subsidies, however, 
alter behavior in a way that undermines their very objective. Fossil-fuel subsidies result in either 
excessive production or consumption, sending wrong signals that distort markets and produce 
uneconomic  outcomes.  And  because  of  the  premium  given  to  fossil-fuels  through  these 
subsidies,  they  also  discourage  the  development  and  deployment  of  renewable  and  more 
efficient, cleaner forms of energy. 
 
2.  At their summit on November 2010, leaders of the Group of Twenty (G-20) countries 
agreed to ―rationalize and phase out over the medium term inefficient fossil-fuel subsidies.‖ 
There is recognition that the timing has to be based on national circumstances and targeted 
support has to be provided for the poorest.1 The joint report to the G-20 by the International 
Energy  Agency  and  three  other  major  organizations  estimates  that  phasing  out  fossil-fuel 
subsidies could reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 10% in 2050 compared with the business-
as-usual scenario.2 Rationalization of these subsidies will also free funds for other uses. Such 
savings could increase the social protection budget to enable the poor to cope with higher 
energy prices. The funds may alternatively be used to improve the welfare of the poor by 
providing them access to affordable modern energy services while reducing the health hazards 
they face from the use of fossil fuels. Finally, these savings could be directed toward supporting 
energy efficiency and renewable energy to help shift economies to a low-carbon growth path. 
 
3.  The 2008 Technical Assistance Strategic Forum of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
established the major areas for research through ADB's research and development technical 
assistance  (TA)  program.  For  2009–2011,  the  five  strategic  priorities  for  research  are 
(i) promoting  inclusive  growth,  (ii)  addressing  climate  change,  (iii) facilitating  knowledge  for 
regional  integration,  (iv) providing  support  to  address  increasing  commodity  prices,  and 
(v) assessing and responding to demographic change. This TA will address priority areas (i), (ii), 
and (iv) of the Forum by generating knowledge products on inclusive growth, climate change, 
and rising energy prices for sustainable development. 
   
II.  ISSUES 
4.  According  to  the  World  Energy  Outlook  2010,  fossil-fuel  consumption  subsidies 
worldwide reached $312 billion in 2009. This varies widely with fluctuations in international 
energy prices, and differences in national pricing policies, exchange rates, and consumption 
levels. Countries with the highest subsidies in absolute terms in 2009 were those that are 
endowed with substantial energy resources: Iran ($66 billion), Saudi Arabia ($35 billion), and the 
Russian Federation ($34 billion). Among the net importing countries with the highest subsidies 
in absolute terms were India ($21 billion) and the People’s Republic of China ($19 billion), but 
their subsidies were lower than those of most of the other countries on a per capita basis or as a 
proportion of gross domestic product.3 
                                                
1  The G-20 Seoul Summit Leaders’ Declaration. 11–12 November 2010. 
http://www.g20.org/Documents2010/11/seoulsummit_declaration.pdf 
2  International Energy Agency, Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, Organisation for Economic 
Co-operation and Development, World Bank. 2010. Analysis of the Scope of Energy Subsidies and Suggestions for 
the G-20 Initiative. http://www.worldenergyoutlook.org/docs/G20_Subsidy_Joint_Report.pdf  
3   International Energy Agency. 2010. World Energy Outlook 2010. Paris.

2   
 
5.  The need for large quantities of energy in rapidly growing economies was evident in the 
international energy market in mid-2008, when oil prices reached over $140 per barrel. Though 
the markets responded to increased energy demand, the high price also tilted the balance of 
economic power in favor of energy-rich countries. This effect was exacerbated when, after 
declining substantially, oil prices once again crossed the $100 per barrel mark in January 2011.  
 
6.  With rising energy prices in recent past, low-income countries have been confronted with 
a  strong  and  consistent  increase  in  the fiscal  cost  of  energy  subsidies,  undermining  their 
development efforts. Subsidizing fossil-fuel consumption leads to increased demand for the 
highly scarce energy source. Higher domestic demand puts pressure on energy imports for 
importing countries or lowers export of energy products in exporting countries, which worsens 
the trade balance. Subsidies to fossil-fuel producers also create excessive supply, which may 
lead to an early depletion of reserves that in some countries represent the main or only source 
of foreign exchange earnings. This implicit incentive to fossil-fuels has created a disincentive for 
the development and rapid deployment of renewable energy and therefore, stunted the pursuit 
of countries for low-carbon growth.  
 
7.  The avowed objective of fossil-fuel consumption subsidies is to redistribute income to 
the poor. This, however, was debunked by an International Monetary Fund study cited in the 
World Energy Outlook 2010, which estimated that ―80% of the total benefits from petroleum 
subsidies in 2009 accrued to the richest 40% of households‖ because the rich consume more 
energy than the poor (footnote 3). As a proportion of income, however, fossil-fuel subsidies 
could be substantial and elimination of such subsidies would still have adverse impact on the 
poor. 
 
8.  Production and consumption subsidies are the more common and explicit forms of fossil-
fuel subsidies. There are, however, myriad other forms that are less obvious or not easily 
captured,  both  in  form  and  the  mechanisms  through  which  they  are  transmitted.  Energy 
subsidies play a critical role in the economic and social development of a country. Designed and 
implemented well, subsidies can help achieve more efficient outcomes. The contextual analysis 
of the reform of inefficient energy subsidies will help policy makers design energy subsidies in 
an environmentally, socially, and economically sound manner. The challenge is to come up with 
ways and means to meet the needs of a country and its people for affordable modern energy 
services while tackling climate change and other environmental issues. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
9.  The TA will develop a theoretical and empirical framework to define and measure fossil-
fuel subsidies and assess the socioeconomic impact of the elimination of fossil-fuel subsidies in 
selected ADB developing member countries (DMCs) from the World Energy Outlook 2010 list of 
countries with high fossil-fuel subsidies. These are Bangladesh, the People’s Republic of China, 
India, Indonesia, Kazakhstan, Malaysia, Pakistan, Thailand, and Uzbekistan. The TA may also 
include other large energy-consuming countries like the Republic of Korea, the Philippines, and 
Viet Nam. The TA findings are expected to provide a benchmark for future detailed, country-
specific studies. The study will have two components. 
 
10.  The first component will constitute a discussion and clarification of suitable definitions of 
fossil-fuel subsidy and its estimation across selected DMCs. Both consumer and producer 
subsidies will be considered to the extent that relevant data are available. Where the definition 
of subsidies (including indirect subsidies such as cross-subsidies) entails problematic issues or

3 
if data are inaccessible, estimates of subsidies from other sources may be used. The findings 
will inform about the types of subsidies being implemented, mechanisms (some implicit) through 
which they are given, and the economic sectors that are benefiting. The coverage is expected to 
account for a major fraction of the fossil-fuel subsidies in all ADB DMCs. 
 
11.  The second component will evaluate household-specific impacts from the elimination of 
subsidies and the consequent short- and medium-term rise in energy prices, and discuss the 
design of social safety nets to mitigate these impacts on the poor, considering gender equity. In 
defining  social  safety-net  mechanisms,  contextual  variations  (e.g.,  institutional  and  political 
environments) of countries will be taken into account. The study will make use of existing data 
from household surveys and, where necessary, may include small surveys with qualitative 
assessment to reveal the household impacts. The benefit-incidence analysis of households will 
be used to determine the need for developing social safety-net mechanisms to protect the poor 
against a likely rise in energy prices as the subsidies are eliminated. 
   
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The impact will be more efficient use of energy, less environmental pollution, and better 
safety nets to protect the poor.  
 
13.  The outcome will be that target DMCs will have a better understanding of fossil-fuel 
subsidies and the implications of phasing it out for poor households.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The TA activities will include the development of conceptual frameworks for the two 
components  of  the  study,  gathering  of  data,  in-country  surveys  if  necessary,  hiring  of 
consultants,  meetings  and  workshops  involving  internal  and  external  stakeholders,  and 
dissemination seminars. 
 
15.  The main TA output will be the completed study to focus renewed attention of DMCs on 
the detrimental impact of rising fossil-energy use on climate change, the issues of subsidies on 
fossil fuel that undermine the pursuit of sustainable development, and social protection for the 
poor.  
 
16.  Data  will  largely  be  collected  from  secondary  sources  to  the  extent  available  and 
applicable. If required, more detailed data will be gathered from the representative DMCs to get 
the characteristics of local markets, economic structure, industrial composition, types of energy 
subsidies, household characteristics, and other information, as necessary. Rigorous analytical 
methods, econometric techniques, and other modeling approaches will be used in the analysis, 
including developing some scenario analyses. 
 
17.  Workshops,  country  seminars,  and  conferences  will  be  organized  to  consult  with 
governments and other stakeholders and to disseminate the findings of the research study. The 
inception workshop, to which high-caliber resource persons and economists will be invited, will 
refine the research problems to be tackled, the analytical framework to be used, and the study 
methodology to be applied. Representatives from the government, the private sector, academe, 
and multilateral organizations will be invited to country seminars and conferences to exchange 
ideas, take stock of lessons from the TA, examine its contributions, and chart the way forward.

4   
18.  Analytical papers produced under the TA will be published in different formats such as 
working papers, policy notes, briefs, and journal articles. The final TA findings will be published 
in a form that could be used as a framework by DMCs in reforming their energy sectors and 
instituting mechanisms to protect the poor from the resulting economic changes. The output will 
not be designed as a policy prescription but as a guidepost to policy making. To this end, an 
emphasis will be placed on the qualitative and quantitative impacts of subsidies on different 
parts of the economy rather than on the size of the estimated subsidy. 
 
19.  Several DMCs that are members of the G-20 and Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation4 
will concurrently examine the fossil-fuel subsidy issues under the action plans of the respective 
organizations. The ADB study team will coordinate with the experts concerned to build synergy 
and  complementarities  in  the  research  and  policy  recommendations.  The  selection  and 
participation of DMCs will be sought after the inception workshop, i.e., when governments have 
clarity regarding the scope and design of the study. 
 
20.  The team will also need to manage expectations—the scope is extensive given the 
different types of fossil-fuel subsidies, and because nearly all sectors are affected by pricing 
decisions  in  the  economies  to  be  analyzed.  A  suitable  analytical  framework  needs  to  be 
developed to bring together the two components—quantifying fossil-fuel subsidy and mitigating 
household impacts for the poor. It will be difficult in this initial study to define all the policy 
options linked to phasing out energy subsidies in Asia and the Pacific; however, the intent would 
be  to  analyze  several  representative  economies  (e.g., exporting  or  importing,  with  mainly 
industrial  or  household  energy  consumption,  or  with  market-based  or  administered  pricing 
mechanisms). Owing to the limitations, the DMCs would not be expected to directly act on the 
conclusions  of  the  study.  Follow-on  country  studies  would  be  necessary  to  (i) assess  the 
impacts of removing fossil-fuel subsidies on broad macroeconomic indicators such as fiscal 
balance, trade balance, industrial structure and employment; and (ii) develop relevant action 
plans, including an effective communications program, for phasing out fossil-fuel subsidy as 
appropriate social protection measures are established. 
 
21.  The aim is to complete the preliminary draft of the first component of the study around 
January 2012, with the final draft by February 2012, and the first draft of the second component 
by March 2012, with the final draft by April 2012. Although an initial publication of the integrative 
report of the study  is expected to be available October 2012, the final publication will be 
released in January 2013.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
22.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The financing will 
cover  remuneration  and  travel  expenses  of  international  and  national  consultants;  survey, 
consultations  and  workshops;  reports  and  communications;  and  contingency.  The  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
23.  The  executing  agency  will  be  the  Asian  Development  Bank  and  the  implementing 
agencies will be the Regional and Sustainable Development Department and the Economics 
                                                
4  These DMCs are the People’s Republic of China; Hong Kong, China; India; Indonesia; the Republic of Korea; 
Malaysia; Papua New Guinea; the Philippines; Singapore; Taipei,China; Thailand; and Viet Nam.

5 
and Research Department. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). An ADB-
wide  study  team  has  been  established  with  nominations  from  various  departments.  More 
nominations, including international and national staff in the respective resident missions, may 
be sought from the regional departments once the DMCs are determined. A steering committee 
(comprising the directors general of the Regional and Sustainable Development Department 
and  one  regional  department,  and  the  chief  economist  of  the  Economics  and  Research 
Department) will provide direction to the team and give the final sign-off on the TA outputs. The 
TA will commence in August 2011 and be completed by January 2013. No-objection will be 
obtained from governments of relevant countries prior to implementing any planned activity. 
 
24.  The TA will require the services of nine international consultants (total of 27 person-
months) and 12 national consultants (total of 54 person-months). The consulting team will 
comprise (i) an international energy economist (lead consultant), (ii) an international public 
finance and energy specialist, (iii) 6 international resource persons, (iv) an international copy 
editor, (v) 10 national economists, (vi) a national logistics coordinator,  and (vii) a national 
research  analyst.  The  logistics  coordinator  will  manage  day-to-day  communications  and 
logistics among all stakeholders and keep track of implementation. The research analyst will 
support the development of a complete database on all the information collected during TA 
implementation to generate longer-term benefits from the TA for ADB and the DMCs. ADB will 
recruit the consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). A consulting firm will be selected to provide specialists (i), (ii), and 
(v) according to quality- and cost-based selection procedures. As the contract budgets for this 
component are less than $1,000,000, simplified technical proposals will be requested from 
short-listed  firms.  The  standard  quality–cost  ratio  of  80:20  will  be  applied.  The  remaining 
consultants will be recruited as individual consultants. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for the Assessment and Implications of Rationalizing and Phasing Out Fossil-Fuel Subsidies, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  International Consulting Firm 
 
1.  Energy economist and lead consultant (1 international, 7 person-months, intermittent). 
The  lead  consultant  will  have  a  university  degree  in  economics,  preferably  a  PhD,  with 
extensive experience in analyzing energy subsidies in Asia. The international expert should also 
have a proven track record serving as a project advisor or team leader in similar assignments, 
and demonstrated capacity to synthesize complex issues and key policy messages for policy 
makers, development partners, and other key stakeholders. The main responsibilities of the 
lead consultant will be the following: 
 
(i)  review relevant literature and prepare a background issues paper leading to an 
suitable design and framework for the conduct of the study in selected ADB 
developing member countries (DMCs); 
(ii)   lead  and  collaborate  with  the  other  consultants  to  prepare  two  reports,  on 
(a) estimating fossil-fuel subsidies and (b) assessing household-specific impacts 
and the social safety-net requirements to mitigate the effects of removing these 
subsidies; 
(iii)  provide advice and guidance to the other consultants in the team, including 
critically reviewing and commenting on their reports; 
(iv)   present  the  issues  paper  at  the  TA  inception  workshop  and  the  reports  at 
conferences  and  workshops,  as  required,  and  incorporate  the  comments 
received; 
(v)   consolidate the final reports from the two components into a single report;  
(vi)  perform  other  tasks  that  may  be  required  to  ensure  successful  and  timely 
completion of the study; and 
(vii)  regularly inform responsible ADB staff of developments in the study and progress 
of the report. 
 
2.  Public finance and energy specialist (1 international, 9 person-months, intermittent). 
The specialist will have a degree in economics, preferably a PhD, with demonstrated experience 
in  analyzing  public  finance,  social  protection,  and  energy  issues,  preferably  in  Asia.  In 
coordination with the lead consultant, the specialist will be responsible for further detailing of the 
concept, design, and methodology to undertake the  study. The tasks of the specialist will 
include, but not be limited to, the following: 
 
(i)  review relevant literature and provide necessary inputs to the lead consultant in 
conducting the study; 
(ii)  lead and guide the national consultants (economists) in estimating fossil-fuel 
subsidies in selected ADB DMCs and analyzing the impact of a removal of these 
subsidies on households; 
(iii)   help prepare, finalize, and consolidate country reports on estimates of fossil-fuel 
subsidies, and assessments of household-specific impacts and social safety-net 
requirements when removing these subsidies; 
(iv)   participate in TA workshops and consultations to present the findings of the 
research study to key stakeholders; and 
(v)   perform  other  tasks  that  may  be  required  to  ensure  successful  and  timely 
completion of the study.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
3.  Economists with specialization in social protection or public finance (10 national, 
3 person-months  each,  intermittent).  The  national  experts  will  have  (i)  a  degree  in  social 
sciences, preferably in economics; (ii) expert knowledge of energy, fiscal, and social policy 
issues in the selected country in particular and developing Asia in general; and (iii) experience 
in both quantitative and policy-oriented analysis using household survey data or micro-level data. 
 
4.  Under  the supervision  of  the  international  public  finance  and  energy  specialist,  the 
national experts will be responsible for preparing country-specific reports on (i) estimating fossil-
fuel subsidies and (ii) assessing the impact on households from removing such subsidies and 
the social safety-net requirements to mitigate these effects, taking into account comments 
received from reviewers in the course of the TA.  
 
5.  The experts will also participate in the workshops and consultations, as needed, to 
disseminate the research findings to relevant stakeholders. 
 
B.  Individual Consultants 
6.  Resource  persons—with  specialization  in  public  finance,  social  protection  or 
energy economics (6 international, 1.5 person-months). The resource persons will be engaged 
to participate as discussants in the midterm review workshop and finalization conference. The 
resource  persons  should  have  (i) expert  knowledge  of  public  economics  and  development 
issues in Asia; and (ii) extensive experience in applied economic research and development 
policy. 
 
7.  Copy editor and typesetter (1 international, 2 person-months). Under the supervision 
of the team leader, a copy editor and typesetter will be engaged to ensure that materials for the 
book adhere to ADB style and conform to high publication standards. The copy editor and 
typesetter will lay out the text, tables, charts, and convert the files into the required format for 
publication. The consultant should possess expertise in copyediting and desktop publishing, and 
preferably have extensive experience in similar assignments involving preparation of economic 
publications. 
 
8.   Logistics coordinator (1 national, 12 person-months, full-time). The coordinator will 
work under the direction and supervision of the team leader. The coordinator will 
 
(i)   support the team leader in preparing meetings, including logistical elements, 
documentation, secretariat services, dissemination of information and materials, 
and related support; 
(ii)   reimburse selected participants for travel, hotel and per diem, and incidental 
expenses; 
(iii)   conduct the financing arrangement for the preparation of technical papers and 
post-workshop and program publications; and 
(iv)   assist the team leader in the management of the day-to-day activities of the TA. 
 
9.   Research analyst (1 national, 12 person-months, full-time). The research analyst will 
have a master’s degree in economics with experience in macroeconomics and/or energy sector 
and will work under the direction and supervision of the team leader. The analyst will 
 
(i)   provide research and technical assistance to the team leader and other members
